context: Approximately 90% of the local citizens rely on public transport facilities for their daily commuting (ISD, 2002a). There is a comprehensive public transport network providing convenient access to every corner of Hong Kong. Everyday, more than 11 million passenger journeys are made on the public transportation modes, which include three railway systems, buses, trams, public light buses, taxis and ferries (Transport Department, 2001). The primary interest of this study is to examine the exposure levels of benzene, toluene, ethylbenzene and m/p/o-xylene (BTEX) in different popular public commuting microenvironments. These six compounds are strongly associated with vehicular emission and widely monitored in traffic-related microenvironments such as vehicle cabins and roadside sites. A total of nine popular public transportation modes in Hong Kong were monitored in this study.
